user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_GenericClose_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_GenericClose_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                             result;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    result = close(impl->fd);
    if (result < 0)
    {
        /*
         * close() can technically fail for various reasons, but
         * there isn't much recourse if this call fails.  Just log
         * the failure for debugging.
         *
         * POSIX also does not specify the state of the filehandle
         * after a close() with an error.
         *
         * At least in  Linux/glibc the filehandle is always closed
         * in the kernel and should not be used again or re-closed.
         */
        OS_DEBUG("close: %s\n", strerror(errno));
    }
    impl->fd = -1;
    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_GenericClose_Impl:
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct
{
    int  fd;
    bool selectable;
} OS_impl_file_internal_record_t
...
extern OS_impl_file_internal_record_t OS_impl_filehandle_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the target function and the provided related definitions for any use of the standard library function memcmp or any apparent use of memcmp to compare null-terminated strings. No occurrences were found in the function body, in the macros shown (OS_DEBUG, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET), or in the small inline helper (OS_ObjectIndexFromToken). The only C standard/POSIX library calls present are close() and strerror(), neither of which is memcmp nor used to compare strings. There are also no explicit string comparison operations (e.g., strcmp, strncmp, or memcmp) in the supplied code. Therefore there are no code fragments that need to be investigated for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 in the provided snippets.
